title: Is it better to sleep naked or wear pyjamas? | ABC NEWS
description: Pending further research for the 'one leg in, one leg out' strategy.  ABC reporter Kellie Scott reports on how what you wear to bed can affect sleep quality. She interviews sleep expert Kathleen Maddison from the Centre for Sleep Science at the University of Western Australia. Kellie appears in pyjamas, using a bed and an eye mask as part of the set and costume. The video features a mixed-media graphic style. title: Did Venezuela steal American oil and assets? | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Donald Trump's justification for the US operation to capture Nicolas Maduro included claims Venezuela had "unilaterally seized and stole American oil, American assets and American platforms". title: As Gen Z moves into work how's it affecting the workplace? | ABC NEWS
description: Gen z employees are posting social media videos of themselves singing and dancing with their older co-workers, showcasing positive relationships between colleagues from different generations.   With the national retirement age rising to 67, generational diversity in Australian workplaces is increasing.   According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, health care, social assistance, education, and training are some of the most age-diverse industries.  Reporting by Chelsea Malunga. title: Ten people convicted of cyberbullying French First Lady Brigitte Macron | ABC NEWS
description: Ten people have been found guilty of cyberbullying France’s First Lady Brigitte Macron by wrongly claiming she was born a male. One defendant was sentenced to six months in prison, while eight were handed suspended sentences between two and eight months. All 10 were mandated to attend cyberbullying awareness training. title: Maduro and wife plead not guilty to drug and weapons charges in New York | ABC NEWS
description: Venezuela's Nicolas Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores have entered a plea of not guilty to all charges in a Manhattan federal court. When asked to introduce himself, the seized Venezuelan leader claimed he had been kidnapped from his home in Caracas. Defence attorney Barry Pollack says he will challenge the legality of the US military’s operation to capture the foreign head of state.  Judge Alvin Hellerstein has scheduled the couple’s next court appearance for March 17th. title: 'I am innocent': Deposed Venezuelan leader enters plea | ABC NEWS
description: Ousted Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores have pleaded not guilty to multiple charges, including narco-terrorism, in their first court appearance since being captured by US forces.  Mr Maduro has led the South American country since 2013, succeeding former president Hugo Chavez.  In the years since, he has overseen a collapse in Venezuela's economy, instituted crackdowns on political opponents, and faced allegations of electoral fraud during 2024's presidential election.  In recent months, the Trump administration has conducted a pressure campaign against Mr Maduro's government, alleging the Venezuelan leader is the unofficial leader of drug cartel Cártel de los Soles. title: Massive sinkhole opens on Melbourne sports field | ABC NEWS
description: A giant sinkhole has opened up on a sports field in Heidelberg in Melbourne’s northeast. Emergency authorities have closed the oval and declared the area off-limits as investigations begin. However, locals are questioning whether underground tunnelling works for the North East Link road project caused the collapse. description: If you see roadkill, what's your first instinct?  In the NSW regional town of Armidale, locals pull over, wrap it up, and drop it off at the Natural History Museum. title: US's Maduro capture criticised at UN Security Council | ABC NEWS
description: China and Russia have been joined by a number of other countries in criticising the US capture of Venezuelan president Nicolas Maduro, as the United Nations Security Council held an emergency session. Beijing labelled the US operation an ‘illegal’ and ‘bullying’ act, while Moscow called it an act of ‘armed aggression. Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Cuba and Columbia joined the two permanent Security Council members in criticising the move, while Argentina and Latvia endorsed the US Ambassador’s argument that the seizure was a law enforcement operation. title: Does the US have jurisdiction to try Nicolas Maduro for drug charges? | ABC NEWS
description: Nicolas Maduro faces a number of charges in the United States after being captured by US forces in Venezuela. Clark Neily from the Cato Institute says Maduro's forcible capture should not be an issue for the prosecution, but there are a number of constitutional issues which might be an avenue for the former Venezuelan president's defence team. description: Health authorities in New South Wales and South Australia are warning of a potential measles outbreak. title: Top democrat accuses Trump of lying to Americans about 'unauthorised' Venezuela raid | ABC NEWS
description: Top Democrat and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries has slammed the Trump administration for the US attack on Venezuela, saying the 'unprecedented' military action lacked legal authorisation. He says the raid  'wasn’t a law enforcement action' and that the administration is 'lying to the American people.' He also acknowledges that Nicolas Maduro is a 'bad guy' and dictator but said the future of Venezuela needs to be determined by the people of Venezuela, not Donald Trump, Pete Hegseth or Stephen Miller. title: Australia’s southeast braces for worst heatwave since Black Summer bushfires | ABC NEWS
description: Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales are forecast to swelter through the most significant heatwave in six years, with temperatures predicted to exceed 40 degrees in Melbourne and Adelaide.  High to extreme fire danger is expected due to moderate winds, dry air and extreme heat across the region.  The Bureau of Meteorology’s Angus Hines is urging residents take ‘extra caution’ in activities with a high fire risk.
